comments.commentBody:
I've had several dogs, and the one with the most spunk, the most character, and also the longest-lived (born in Cleveland and died in Vienna, Austria) was a mixed breed i. e. mutt. I don't object to the word, since to me it reminds me of that feisty toy terrier with chihuahua ears.

I am Ashkenazy Jewish on both sides as far back as I can tell, although having been a red-head I suspect that there might be some other strain in there. But my extended family is a rainbow coalition: my son is Jewish on both sides, my brother's three have a Mexican mother, and my sisters' three are: 2 half AA and one whose grandfather is an Episcopalian minister. here in New York, I hear people speaking Turkish, Tadzhik, Armenian, Swiss German, and of course, am surrounded by Spanish here in Washington Heights.

I love it. And I hope to whatever Power there be that when the seas rise and weather patterns change unpredictably, when the West becomes a desert and Montauk washes away, that it will somehow survive. But given the mentality (?) of our "pure-bred" politicians and power-mongers, I am not optimistic.

It's one thing to refer to yourself self-deprecatingly as a "mutt." It's an entirely different thing to say that a people who were once ethnically European (i.e., white) become "mutts" by mixing with people from Asia, Latin American and Africa (i.e., not white).

politicsbyeccehomo.wordpress.com

"Mutt" can be pejorative, neutral or positive, depending on the context.

As a typical American "mutt", I am proud of my heritage, and for me, like Susan, mutt is a positive term. Although my ancestors are very different from each other in many ways, they shared courage and hope when they immigrated to the US in search of a better life for themselves and their children.

I agree with Mr. Brooks that the future of our country is indeed exciting. We are blessed with diversity, however you wish to name it.

I'm OK with the term mutt, since it's my favorite dog breed, and also because I myself am of muttish background. Anyone who claims to be 100% any ethnicity had better have an awful lot of documentation, and definitive proof that no one was fooling around on anyone way back when. Lots of surprises turn up.

I think what Mr. Brooks describes is likely coming, and the sooner the better. Let's celebrate mutthood one and all, and not get hung up on various connotations or the appropriateness of a term. What other term should he use? Hybrid perhaps?6

"are severely distorting their pension numbers by failing to take proper account of market risks"

I suppose it's human nature to not want to face up to negative facts, hoping that by ignoring a problem, it just might, somehow, go away and leave you looking smarter than you really are. Hmmm, used to be that sort of situation was accounted for by a "contingencies" entry on the books.

Considering that the failure to properly account for market risks is something that is within their control and is an actual contingency, how might they account for something that is totally outside of their control, such as a theft, where foreign hackers might reduce a state's deposit balances by a few hundred million dollars? Would they think they would be justified in throwing up their hands and proclaiming an act of God - "how could we have expected that to happen?"

In a world where it more and more seems anything is possible? They'd better get serious. Too bad there is no one actually looking out for the taxpayers, because one day we're likely to wake up to just that sort of news story.
The payroll tax isn't just some amorphous income - it's dedicated to Social Security and Medicare. Playing fast and loose with it is (typical) political madness.

We need a war on coal not only to slow global warming but also to save the 10,000 Americans that soot and other forms of air pollution from coal-fired power plants kill each year. The figure in China may be as high as a million. Coal is enemy number 1.

A renewal of Obama's cut in the payroll tax would help the poor and boost demand.

It's about time! But Obama's sincerity will be determined by his decision on Keystone. The problem with the tar sands oil is that it takes so much energy to produce it; one barrel of tar sands oil is equivalent to about 3 barrels of oil from a well. And don't think the tar sands oil is going to get out some other way; British Columbia just rejected a new pipeline for the tar sands oil.

The core economic issue of our time is the alarming CO2 curve. That CO2 curve is threatening to become an exponential. it is augmenting at 1% a year. This CO2 curve is the core survival issue of our time. Every day, the deep oceans are getting warmer, more acidic (the CO2 gets in the sea, turning it to a soda), and lose oxygen. Every day, the deepest currents are absorbing the new energy, modifying themselves.

At any point, any day, formidable non linear mechanisms independent of man, caused by the effects of the CO2 increase could get in gear. For example enormous, sudden releases of methane hydrates causing tsunamis (accelerating considerably the greenhouse, as methane is twenty to a hundred time more of a greenhouse gas).
http://patriceayme.wordpress.com/2009/05/15/terminal-problem-final-solut...

A slow-down of the sun has bought up some time, in the last decade. However most of the carbon has been buried for hundreds of millions of years. Extracting, and throwing it in the air, is sheer insanity. This has got to stop.

Managing the planet correctly is real economics, much more than the shenanigans of some central bankers. Moreover, the only way for the most economically advanced countries to stay advanced is by developing, and imposing, advanced technologies. That can only work when it is sustainable, that is, moral. This is what morality means.

Even when all US coal consumption is replaced by natural gas, your annual per capita carbon footprint will fall only to 14t CO2. Paying one or two Cents more per kWh won't kill you or any American industry.

"But wouldn’t imposing carbon limits raise the cost of electricity? And wouldn’t that destroy jobs? The answer is, yes and no."

"It’s always important to remember that what ails the U.S. economy right now isn’t lack of productive capacity, but lack of demand."

It will be years before these regulations are final. If the economy has recovered by the time the new regs have an effect on coal fired plants and the lack of demand is over then they just raise costs, they make our productions cost higher, and make us less competitive in the global economy. So isn't the answer "yes and maybe?"

If we could start building gas-electricity plants now to replace those coals plants that would help employment. But we can't. And when we can build them we don't know if we will still have lack of demand.

As you say, the costs are unknown. It seems likely that natural gas may be so cheap that amortization of the capital costs of the new gas-electricity plants will be offset substantially by the lower fuel costs.

The supporters of this legislation think they are pursuing political advantage, but what they actually may be doing is sowing the seeds for a huge political backlash, once it becomes obvious to Americans that a broad swath of our citizenry is being sold out in favor of vote-hungry politicians, corporations eager to cut labor costs even further, and military contractors trolling for still more pork. I NEVER thought I would be thankful to the current House, but if they block this, even for all the wrong reasons, many of us will feel we owe them one, possibly in the form of being no-shows in the next election or two.

Unbelievable that these Senators are congratulating themselves for this awkward Bill. They want to spend 40 Billion dollars on a fence and 20,000 patrols. 40 BILLION! The greed associated with this issue is gross. My father was a union organizer. Men and women like him sacrificed so we could enjoy  our work related benefits. But business has found a way to work people 60 hours a week, offer no overtime, healthcare, pay minimum wages and work them in the worst conditions. Americans do not know what is going on in these labor industries. Its awful. Politicians have deliberately been looking the other way because of the greed factor for business. Instead of holding Mexico to the fire for it's un willingness to move it's people out of poverty; Instead we  just play along and impoverish them here  or use them for cheap labor and let hard working middle class Americans foot the bill for their education, housing and healthcare. Is there any wonder why so many people are seething over this issue? As a hard working middle class American struggling year to year just to maintain ,sometimes falling back, the fact that our Government has deliberately  chosen to ignore it's own laws on immigration enforcement makes me loose all respect all  for this nations leaders.

Well, if you are a student and you want to study some subject or other then you are responsible for the debt you incur. What I wouod suggest is that the $40 billion debt that is incurred to insure the nation's security and integrity is the responsibility of the 11 million illegal immigrants. They should have to pay a "sur" tax. No pun intended. Whatever they pay in taxes will hardly make up for what they are costing, otherwise. They should respect boundaries or pay severe penalties.

Why are the Democrats so anxious to help the Republicans out of their dilemma? The question and problem of undocumented foreign residents has boiled up since the days of Ronnie Reagan, but suddenly last year's election results shocked the Republicans, at least those in the Senate, into think they must do something. This is the usual pattern: the Democrats trade getting a bill through, in exchange they let the Republicans out of the corner they have been painting themselves into for a long time.

I can only hope that Obama, the president who is now getting a firm reputation for unfirmness and compromise above all else, finds the nerve to veto any legislation that does not provide a way to resolve this issue in all of its tangled aspects. Half a loaf is better than nothing? All that leads to is the Republicans asking, "Will you take 1/4?" When the answer comes back yes, then they decide to provide 1/8th.

The biggest problem is resolving undocumented immigration is the demagogic posturing of cheap politicians. America can solve its problems, if only we could push the political sideshow out of the way.

Not sure comparing USA/Mexico border to the inner-German border is a good comparison. GDR (east germany) was a state controlled economy trying to keep their population from escaping GDR devoted a huge amount of the country's money to fortifying the border and maintaining the border fortification and secret police. Do we want to do that? The inner-german border was land mined. Do we want that? The inner-german border had a huge negative impact on the economies on either side. want that?

We can spend billions on fortifying our border, but if people want to get in, they will. It's a huge border and people can tunnel, cut fences, and even take boats and enter via the also huge coasts. spending large sums on border fortifications seems like a huge waste at a time when we have other pressing needs.

They say now this will be a tough one for the Republican led House.
No doubt, they haven't yet graduated from the basic course in 'House 1A'.

All change and especially sweeping change that will alter our country forever, like immigration reform, the negatives as well as the positives regarding its multi layered impact must be considered.

Presently, the major pro appears to be political, appears to be simplistic vote getting. People, citizen and undocumented, are an aside. And that's disturbing to say the least. It's time we demand a clear bipartisan list of pros and cons for all to see. And in retrospect, it's utterly shocking that this law has already passed the Senate without one.

A list of postive and negative consequences is necessary not only so we can be assured that our representatives are making a well thought out decision with as complete a picture and understanding as possible, but so we citizens can likewise make up our own minds.

Important decisions, like this, must be reality based. And in the real world there are both positive and negative consequences, as well as, unintended ones. Once a list has been honestly and authentically compiled and agreed on, the question then becomes which one wins out.

On top of that,  not prior to 10 years after the act is in effect, can anyone be granted citizenship.  Cut that loaf down to two  slices. You'll be hungry tomorrow.  Ten more years... give me a break.  This is just a poor attempt at a political show toward the Latino community.  I hope they actually read the bill and realized that this is just a dangling carrot just out of reach.  Fencing?  What does, how does that help the people already here? That's 10 more years of stalliing. Even if they built the fence tomorrow, the bill still holds citizenship hostage for 10 more years.  That's stated at the very beginning of the bill, which in my opinion, makes the rest of it not worth reading.

Thank you mmpack for pointing out that playing the race card is no way to keep the channels of communication open. I agree with George Dover in an earlier email. Population growth is something that we should be thinking about and uncontrolled immigration can and has added to ours. We are already straining many of our resources. I personally feel that we should be bringing everyone here illegally out of the shadows but I do worry about chain migration for all sorts of reasons, unsustainable population growth being one of them. And Edward- what about the civil rights of our poorest citizens (who come in all colors btw) of this country who are suffering due to competition from this large undocumented work force. Screaming race every time someone disagrees with you isn't playing fair.

Finally it gets to the House where the bill can go down in defeat. Once this happens the House should rapidly pass a bill ordering the National Guard to sweep the nation of the 11,000,000 criminals who are blatantly living illegally in this country.
After 6 months we will be talking about how there are no longer any illegal aliens left in the US. After a year we wil be a little melancholy that we didn't throw out the bums out sooner.
